I feel a deep and sweet sensation when I think to the Middle East and to its people. It is hard do describe what I really mean but it is something of really deep.
Everytime I have been in Middle East I felt myself at home.

This documentary is incredible!
It is impressive to see all this destruction, and it is difficult to imagine all the pains and atrocities that were committed in that place. It is really impressive to see hope and satisfaction in the eyes of the citizen who works to survive and try to rebuild his life.
I've never seen anything like it.
Congratulations on the work!

As I'm watching this my thoughts go to all the martyrs, the innocent people who have lost their lives or loved ones, the orphaned children, the scenes of war come back to mind, the bombings the ambulances trying to reach but being targetted as well, the hospitals and maternity wards also targetted ruthlessly. My heart aches as I'm seeing these ruins, and I can't help but cry. The people of Syria are jewels on earth, my Algerian parents have never stopped singing their praises.
But as the events unfolded, we couldn't help but feel helpless, we could only help financially and through relaying the events on social media and around us... But inshaAllah justice will prevail, if not in this life then in the other. My prayers go to all of my Syrian brothers and sisters, to all the beautiful children of Syria <3

Syria was the first country I fell in love after Pakistan. I did not even know at that time it called Syria because we call it SHAAM. I was in the early teenage, no internet access, and vlogs were not there to show you.  The only way to know and get knowledge was by reading books. I read a travelogue by a Pakistani writer. he has been to many countries but the way he describes our dear SHAAM was amazing. Even after more than ten years I still remember some lines. "Almost every shaami loves "umm -e-kulsoom". Then if you ask address from the local shaami he will first serve you "kehwa" and then will go with you to the destination. "as I told you he was a Syrian then there is no need to tell that he was beautiful(it is obvious)". so shaam was my dreamland. I wanted to travel and see its people, their hospitality, and their kindness. It was just a perfect crush.  But then that crisis and everything. but it does not break my dream. And after viewing the Vlogs you have made especially of Damascus I am hopeful that Syrians will make a comeback. Time does not remain the same. All dear Syrians will go back to their homeland and will live happily. Insha Allah. My best wishes to all my Syrian brothers and sisters. May Allah help them. Love from Pakistan.

Dear author of the video! I share your desire to stay out of politics on the travel channel. But the trick is that propaganda somehow shapes your worldview, and you can't stay out of politics, especially if we talk about the one-sided position that the German media reports. Why did I bring this up? Because at the very beginning of the video, right after your words about distancing yourself from politics, you say that the parties to the conflict were: the Syrian opposition and the Syrian government. I have a leading question: can those who participated in the "opposition action" in Germany at the Olympic games on September 5, 1972 in Munich be called oppositionists? How would you feel about calling such people "oppositionists" instead of their real name? I don't expect an answer, I don't need your answer. I just want you to think about it for yourself.

I found this video so moving that it brought me to tears.  Although I'm Australian,   I met a Syrian family online about 7 years ago now.  We ended up adopting each other as family.  We have been through the experience of my adopted son when he was feeling very low because he'd had to leave his town near Damascus because he was being dragged off to prison and tortured, because he was educated and owned a thriving business.  He had to flee to a refugee camp in  Jordan so that his pregnant wife and very young son would be safe because when he was taken to the prison, it was from his home, and in front of his young son.  It was not safe for this to happen in front of them. The military had already bombed and totally destroyed his businesses. This was done at the hands of Assad.  His wife and young son eventually joined him in the camp in Jordan leaving everything they had left.  My son gave his house to his sister to live in with her children.  Unfortunately the house had barrel bombs dropped on it a few times, making it impossible for her and her children to live in. Sadly I saw photos of the house after just the first barrel bomb was dropped, and although I could see that it had been a lovely modern home with all of the modern conveniences.  I can't even imagine how my adopted daughter was feeling when she had to leave her lovely home, not only with a young son to care for on her own, but she was also 6 months into her pregnancy.  The conditions in the camp were so poor that the little boy was really suffering with malnutrition.  They managed to find a basement in which to rent just 2 weeks before their beautiful little girl was born. The kitchen sink was all they had in which to bath the baby. They only had one hot plate to prepare and cook food. The rent was too high for them to continue  living there, but they were fortunate enough to find a house to share with a few other Syrian refugee families.  They each only had one bedroom to call their own   with the rest of the areas communal.  I had been doing all I could to sponsor them to come to Australia.  This was taking so much time that my son was becoming so despondent and frustrated that he even considered paying to get a boat to Turkey.   I was so scared that he would actually do this.  However,  his wife became pregnant again, so this was another member of the family for them to worry about, especially as it had been a difficult pregnancy and birth.  However, the wonderful news to hear, was that Canada had so kindly offered to interview them for relocation to Canada and the opportunity to become Canadian permanent residency.  The third baby was only weeks old when they were flown to Canada only 2 months after their first interview!  I can't tell you how thrilled I was for them.  They managed to find a lovely home to rent, including furniture that the owner left there for them.  He had also been a refugee so he understood their situation only too well.  My son already spoke and wrote pretty well in English,  but both he and his wife went to 'school' to become fluent in English.  The children now not only speak their native language,    but now speak English and are also learning French at school.  They each became Naturalized Canadian citizens a few months ago.  This has been a journey of many ups and downs,  but it's one that has had a very, very happy ending!  Of course I receive photos and videos of the children playing outside in the park while calling out to one another when deciding on whicn swings, etc they are going to ride on.  And, for the very happy ending to this story, they had another little boy who was 8 weeks early and so tiny that he had to remain in the humidy crib for the first few months,  but he's also a happy, healthy little Canadian born little boy now!   I still find it hard to believe just how much we have experienced together .... and I am so very proud of them for the resilience they have shown even in the darkest of times.  Not only are they grateful for the opportunity that Canada has given to them, but I also know that Canada will also be proud to have them as citizens of Canada.

I’m Spaniard, and this almost made me cry... My country has a connection with Syria, as long at once people came from there and left their prints in my country in so many ways... I’m glad to see that Damascus hasn’t almost being damaged, but I cried seeing Aleppo, once the pearl of Middle East. But, you know what? We can rebuild the city! Yes, we all, and in my country is also contributing, there’s a project called “Alepoh”, which aim is to make bricks in order to rebuild schools, hospitals, etc, and many of our historical buildings have a “Syrian stamp”, so our architects and historians are also studying ways to rebuild Aleppo as similar as it was, using similar techniques. Syria will rise again, and Aleppo will shine as it used to do it before.

This piece moved me, it brought tears to my eyes. I am not Syrian; nor have I been to Syria; but I did travel in Jordan many years ago and I have seen the souks of Cairo and Istanbul. I sense though that Syria, Syrians and their grand souk were different, expressions of a unique place in human culture and history. I truely mourn that I shall never step into and feel that place with my owe flesh and blood.  But maybe there is a way through the stories and experience of others and the records they have left. And I pray that the spirit of that place will live on and give rise to a new creation where we can get a direct glimpse of this place and a scent of its dust and spices and ovens, and hear the  beautiful chaotic sounds of its streets. Thank you Eva zu Beck   Don Monroe, Maryland, USA

The same government that bombed the city in the first place, the same government that's currently bombing Idlib, and the same government that thought it was okay to use chemical weapons on its civilians. This kind of peace will not last. True peace will come to Aleppo... but as long as tyrannical dictators like Assad is ruling over it, there will never be justice. And with no justice, comes no peace.

@gentle life  Honestly when the war first started we thought it was gonna be over in a few months, little did we know that the west was backing these terrorists at an extreme point to destabilise Syria and overthrow the current government, the war kept on going until 2015 when one of Syrias allies Russia intervened and helped the Syrian army fight the western backed terrorists, they also helped us with humanitarian aid and vetoing things in the UN, Russia and China used their vetoes in the UN to help Syria. The war continued and now as of January 2021 the Syrian army controls all the major cities and the majority of the country, the terrorists remain in Idlib along the Turkish border where they’re aided by NATO (U.S, Turkey) and Israel even helped fund the terrorists. I now think that the best case scenario is that the war ends this year 2021 however that’s looking unlikely due to ceasefires etc. and a medium case scenario is 2023 and a worst case scenario is 2025. Unfortunately economically the situation is not getting better since the U.S and it’s allies have sanctioned Syria which is resulting in Syria becoming more unliveable since everything have become expensive and the sanctions are also starving people and crippling Syrias already crippled healthcare system. Hopefully the situation will get better however it will need a bit of time. Also in case your wondering I’m half Lebanese and half Syrian.

As a Syrian living currently in Aleppo, I appreciate the beautiful gesture.
Recently, Aleppo's Museum re-opened, and I got to visit it once more, I almost went to tears when to see that we though slowly, the city is trying to stand up again, and we have our history to speak for us. Aleppo is one of humanity's cradles of civilizations and one of the oldest inhabited cities in the world: Wheat agriculture was first discovered here; soup was also invented here, and so many empires rose and fell upon this land.
Though I probably will not witness it myself, I hope one day, Aleppo gets back on its feet.

So there are a bunch of youtubers doing "travel content" in (let´s just say) more or less troubled areas of the world and on the one hand, especially in the case of syria this is a good thing. You are really helping those people getting back on their feet and rebuilding their wartorn country by visiting them, talking to them, of course buying souveniers and showing a quite different of perspective of the country than the media for the last 8-9 years. On the other hand, and this really troubles me not just on your videos but all of those youtubers, those videos are completely uncritical about their own intention. You have to be very very privileged to even come up with the idea of travelling to such places. And even though you try not to be political in this video, one can find postcolonial tendencies at many moments. Of course this is also due to your western socialization but you don´t seem to be aware of this fact.
Also, let´s say you wouldn´t indirectly spread postcolonial views of the not-western world, what if something would actually happen to you? Let´s say you get abducted (and I really hope this never happens to you nor anyone!). Security forces have to go in, risk THEIR lives in order to free you. And if you or one of them dies doing that than what for? For someone who ran around more or less dangerous places just so you can put it on youtube? Would this really be worth risking other peoples lives?

The human tragedy of war is inexcusable. As for the city itself, I am actually quite surprised how quickly it sprung back to a relatively normal life! I was under the impression that basically the whole city was wiped out. But it seems that there are parts where you see almost no signs of war. The Baron Hotel also actually seems in decent shape from the outside. The old souk damage is much more significant but seems repairable. I'm more worried that due to obvious limitations it's probably not gonna be reconstructed into the pre-war historical state, but a wild "modern" rebuilding will take place. Anyway, best luck to people of Aleppo in their return to a normal peaceful life!

Years ago, I met a lady from Aleppo. She was a single mother, hard working, did anything that was honest toil. She would cook for other people, washed and ironed clothes, taught Middle Eastern cookery at night school, etc. She lived in a nice apartment with her son and had a really good life in a very nice part of Melbourne, Australia. And it was all from her hard work, her dedication to giving her son a good life. If she is anything to go by, I have no doubt the people of Syria will be able to rebuild their devastated country.

Thank you for sharing your experience. There is great hope for Syria. We have a Syrian vlogger, here in our country in the Philippines named Basel whos family fled Syria because of the war. His house was bombed into pieces.  He was sent by his father to our country to continue his education. He had a hard time adjusting for 6 months to being alone in a country totally different from his wherein 90% of the people are Christian.  But he adopted very well and our people welcomed and embraced him until he was whole again. He calls the Philippines his home now and loves it here. His youtube channel is called " The Hungry Syrian Wanderer". Hes been a successful vlogger and businessman now here in our country and we embrace his story and treat him like our own  Just like Syria, the Philippines has had its own civil war, political conflicts and had been fighting ISIS in the southern part of our country for decades now. But somehow we are winning because of that human HOPE. Our resilience as a people of peace and kindness has triumped over war. SYRIA will rise again just like us, where Basel can return home. I hope it will be sooner.

Im Syrian and I am born in the US and I got to visit my family in Aleppo after 9 years. I was there the around same time you were, from July to August in 2019. It was terrifying, saddening, yet exciting and it made me happy to see family and the place I had so many amazing memories in. We heard missile launches, explosions and gun shots when we were there but my family said things are much better than a couple years ago where those sounds were much louder and constant along with the low supply of food, water, and electricity. I love my country and I'm happy to see it begin to stand the way it once was.

Who destroyed Syria? Gen. Wesley Clark told who 12 years ago in March 2007. “We’re Going to Take out 7 Countries in 5 Years: Iraq, Syria, Lebanon, Libya, Somalia, Sudan & Iran...”

AMY GOODMAN: Well, for the rest of the hour, we’ll hear General Wesley Clark in his own words on the possibility of a US attack on Iran; the impeachment of President Bush; the use of cluster bombs; the bombing of Radio Television Serbia during the Kosovo War under his command; and much more. I interviewed General Clark on Tuesday at the 92nd Street Y in New York.

AMY GOODMAN: Now, let’s talk about Iran. You have a whole website devoted to stopping war.

GEN. WESLEY CLARK: Www.stopiranwar.com.

AMY GOODMAN: Do you see a replay in what happened in the lead-up to the war with Iraq — the allegations of the weapons of mass destruction, the media leaping onto the bandwagon?

GEN. WESLEY CLARK: Well, in a way. But, you know, history doesn’t repeat itself exactly twice. What I did warn about when I testified in front of Congress in 2002, I said if you want to worry about a state, it shouldn’t be Iraq, it should be Iran. But this government, our administration, wanted to worry about Iraq, not Iran.

I knew why, because I had been through the Pentagon right after 9/11. About ten days after 9/11, I went through the Pentagon and I saw Secretary Rumsfeld and Deputy Secretary Wolfowitz. I went downstairs just to say hello to some of the people on the Joint Staff who used to work for me, and one of the generals called me in. He said, “Sir, you’ve got to come in and talk to me a second.” I said, “Well, you’re too busy.” He said, “No, no.” He says, “We’ve made the decision we’re going to war with Iraq.” This was on or about the 20th of September. I said, “We’re going to war with Iraq? Why?” He said, “I don’t know.” He said, “I guess they don’t know what else to do.” So I said, “Well, did they find some information connecting Saddam to al-Qaeda?” He said, “No, no.” He says, “There’s nothing new that way. They just made the decision to go to war with Iraq.” He said, “I guess it’s like we don’t know what to do about terrorists, but we’ve got a good military and we can take down governments.” And he said, “I guess if the only tool you have is a hammer, every problem has to look like a nail.”

So I came back to see him a few weeks later, and by that time we were bombing in Afghanistan. I said, “Are we still going to war with Iraq?” And he said, “Oh, it’s worse than that.” He reached over on his desk. He picked up a piece of paper. And he said, “I just got this down from upstairs” — meaning the Secretary of Defense’s office — “today.” And he said, “This is a memo that describes how we’re going to take out seven countries in five years, starting with Iraq, and then Syria, Lebanon, Libya, Somalia, Sudan and, finishing off, Iran.” I said, “Is it classified?” He said, “Yes, sir.” I said, “Well, don’t show it to me.” And I saw him a year or so ago, and I said, “You remember that?” He said, “Sir, I didn’t show you that memo! I didn’t show it to you!”

AMY GOODMAN: I’m sorry. What did you say his name was?

GEN. WESLEY CLARK: I’m not going to give you his name.

AMY GOODMAN: So, go through the countries again.

GEN. WESLEY CLARK: Well, starting with Iraq, then Syria and Lebanon, then Libya, then Somalia and Sudan, and back to Iran. So when you look at Iran, you say, “Is it a replay?” It’s not exactly a replay. But here’s the truth: that Iran, from the beginning, has seen that the presence of the United States in Iraq was a threat — a blessing, because we took out Saddam Hussein and the Baathists. They couldn’t handle them. We took care of it for them. But also a threat, because they knew that they were next on the hit list. And so, of course, they got engaged. They lost a million people during the war with Iraq, and they’ve got a long and unprotectable, unsecurable border. So it was in their vital interest to be deeply involved inside Iraq. They tolerated our attacks on the Baathists. They were happy we captured Saddam Hussein.

But they’re building up their own network of influence, and to cement it, they occasionally give some military assistance and training and advice, either directly or indirectly, to both the insurgents and to the militias. And in that sense, it’s not exactly parallel, because there has been, I believe, continuous Iranian engagement, some of it legitimate, some of it illegitimate. I mean, you can hardly fault Iran because they’re offering to do eye operations for Iraqis who need medical attention. That’s not an offense that you can go to war over, perhaps. But it is an effort to gain influence.

And the administration has stubbornly refused to talk with Iran about their perception, in part because they don’t want to pay the price with their domestic — our US domestic political base, the rightwing base, but also because they don’t want to legitimate a government that they’ve been trying to overthrow. If you were Iran, you’d probably believe that you were mostly already at war with the United States anyway, since we’ve asserted that their government needs regime change, and we’ve asked congress to appropriate $75 million to do it, and we are supporting terrorist groups, apparently, who are infiltrating and blowing up things inside Iraq — Iran. And if we’re not doing it, let’s put it this way: we’re probably cognizant of it and encouraging it. So it’s not surprising that we’re moving to a point of confrontation and crisis with Iran.

My point on this is not that the Iranians are good guys — they’re not — but that you shouldn’t use force, except as a last, last, last resort. There is a military option, but it’s a bad one."

In spite of it all, when i saw the people who live there, in this footage, they only reminded me of hope, of moving forward. Hi Eva: I have seen your video and I could feel the same as you on my trip to Damascus, Homs and other places in Syria between September 12 and 19 of this year, that is, a few days ago. It wasn't the first time I went, since I have family in Homs. I absolutely agree with your impact, your pain and your shock at seeing so much destruction and death.
In my tour of Syria I could see the nobility and courage of this beloved people to get ahead. As the grandson of a Syrian emigrant, I thank you very much for your video. I also know that that beloved Syrian people is also grateful for this video. The arrival of people from abroad makes them feel that the situation has improved and that the war is in retreat. Greetings from Chile, South America.

As for the name in foreign languages, Alep and Aleppo are used indiscriminately, although Aleppo is an Italian version of the name in the first place. Aleppo is described in historical records as an important city first mentioned in the third millennium BC, when it was the capital of an independent kingdom linked to Ebla, a kingdom Bebla, the kingdom of Arman or Armi Archaeologist Giovanni Bettinato described the Kingdom of Arman as being similar to the Kingdom of Ebla in narcissism.

Thank you Eva for visiting Aleppo (Halab as it pronounced in Arabic). I have eaten Hatalia at the same exact shop you visited and walked the cobble-stone streets that you walked on.  The destruction of old Aleppo is disheartening. The loss is not just buildings and UNESCO historic sites for Westerner to come and visit. A city is infrastructure, people and history all combined. There is high human, cultural, and traditions costs to the destruction. Houses and business in Aleppo remain in the same family for hundreds of years and often mail addresses and directions are given by family shop or a family-name of the occupant of a house. Just curious,  I was wondering why you did not focus on the Citadel?; which is the trademark of Aleppo. One of the most amazing characters of Aleppo is how diverse its population is and how they coexisted for thousand years in harmony. It is a myth that this crisis was of a civil war. Thank you so much again. Your raw feelings come across as honest and truthful. It touched me. I cried.  Keep on doing the work you do, It helps the world.
